thread.title: Experience is best teacher, and it can pay well, too
thread.title_full: Experience is best teacher, and it can pay well, too

author: Dwight Perry / Sideline Chatter
title: Experience is best teacher, and it can pay well, too
text:
Experience is best teacher, and it can pay well, too Originally published October 22, 2015 at 5:11 pm Professional golfer Rory McIlroy was all set to go to college, but decided to turn pro instead, poor guy. 
Rory McIlroy’s revised college majors: British Open, U.S. Open … 
Seems the Northern Irishman was all set to play for East Tennessee State before abruptly turning pro. 
“I signed a letter-of-intent to play for ETSU, did my SAT, did everything like that,” McIlroy told AP, “so I was fully ready to come over and play college golf. By the time I was probably just getting out of college, I had just won my first major. It was a good decision in the end.” 
No kidding. He’d racked up nearly $4 million in earnings by his 22nd birthday. Headlines 
• At SportsPickle.com: “Report: Louisville unlikely to fire Pitino after top 700 recruits schedule official visits.” 
• At Fark.com: “ESPN to cut 350 jobs, reduce ‘SportsCenter’ to 23.5 hours per day.” Wrong end zone 
The NFL Network apologized to Bengals players who were inadvertently shown nude in the background during a postgame locker-room interview and quickly pulled the offending video. 
As for any unauthorized versions still making the rounds, guess you could call them naked bootlegs. This doesn’t add up 
“Matt Harvey made $614,000 from the Mets this year, while Jacob deGrom made $556,000,” noted Janice Hough of LeftCoastSportsBabe.com. “Together they almost equal the 2015 Mets salary of Bobby Bonilla — $1,193,000.” Pass the red cards 
Some two dozen soccer fans brawled outside Sinclair’s Oyster Bar in Manchester, England, hurling chairs, bicycles and other objects. 
Prosecutors, seeking a punishment that fits the crime, are for itching to administer penalty kicks. Quote marks 
• Patriots D-lineman Alan Branch, as told to The New York Times, after Jets tackle Breno Giacomini asked to exchange jerseys with him after a game last season: “You held me long enough. You might as well take it.” 
• Brad Dickson of the Omaha (Neb.) World-Herald, on the death of Texas Longhorns mascot Bevo XIV: “To give you an idea how important football is in Texas, the governor is giving the eulogy.” 
• Comedy writer Alan Ray, on the 1-5 Detroit Lions: “The only time they’re even money to win is during the coin toss.” 
• Comedy writer Alex Kaseberg, on double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius going from prison to house arrest with an ankle monitor: “Does anyone else see the flaw in this arrangement?” Heard in passing 
Mike Ditka appeared to audibly pass gas during ESPN’s live “Monday Night Countdown” telecast, but he’s denying it. 
DeflateGate II, anyone?
